As JB said- meh at best. I didn't find the puzzle too difficult (about 3 minutes slower than my average Wed. time), in spite of the many pop culture references. I just wish that those references were more interesting. KC Affleck? Really?

I suppose it's easy to just criticize, but although the solving went okay, this just didn't seem like much fun.

Philosophy is anything but a pure meritocracy and this is independent of considerations of bias against women. Philosophy has its fads! It is not unlike the arts. Music conservatories taught Serialism in composition for years. Therefore, composition students were expected to write inaccessible music. Pulitzer Prizes were awarded to the Elliott Carters not because they were the most meritorious composers but because the powers that be liked that sort of music.

That quantified modal logic was the in thing a few years ago was not its inherent superiority to other issues but because that was what was happening at Princeton.

So far, there is NO definitive proof that Assad launched the chemical weapons, but even if he did, it isn't our fight! The rest of the world sees the US as hypocritical, since we've used chemical weapons ourselves and tolerated it when used by others if it suited our purposes. The Arab world will hate us no matter what we do, so let's invest in our own country and let the Middle East solve its own problems.

Are we sure that it was not the rebels who launched these missiles? After the WMD's in the Iraq debacle are Americans really so willing to listen only the facts as presented by our war mongering leaders? And not NATO and many others, even those within Syria, who say that the missiles came from the rebels... It seems that the majority of Americans is skeptical at best, yet those who represent us are displaying the same zeal for war again... Obama pandering to Boehner and McCain to get support after all that has gone down - gun control, healthcare bill, taxes - is sickening to see and evidence that CHANGE was just another election tagline...

Actually, collatoral damage can be zero if it follows the same pattern that Bill Clinton followed when bombing Iraq in 1998. As the media points out, we hit dozens of locations, but since they were obvious targets and we gave so much advance notice that we would punish Saddam by taking out military installations, they had been vacated. See here:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombing_of_Iraq_(1998)
Yes, thank you! Finally I find somebody here who cares for those poor souls.
Well and truly said.

It is not so much a lack of compassion, as it is a lack of viable options. As long as Assad refrained from the wholesale slaughter of innocents--especially children and women, it made sense to keep the Syrian civil war at arm's length. By the way, there are half a dozen hotspots in Africa where human rights abuses and atrocities take place, on a scale akin to what occurs in Syria. But the garner no media attention, and so do not occupy our thoughts....

I voted for Obama twice. I feel betrayed and foolish for believing anything he said. He, like his immediate predecessor, G W Bush, is beholden to the military/industrial complex, not the citizens of this country. He is a fraud and many people will die because of him. How can he and John Kerry live with themselves?

Rebel forces we are going to support have been consistently involved in systematic ethnic cleansing, raping, beheadings, torturing, setting alive people at blaze, killing children, deaths due to lack of medical help after cutting off extremities in punishments executed according to the Sharia law, and terror campaigns.

Of the 100,000 estimated deaths in Syria due to the conflict so far, 30,000 are Syrian government soldiers and approximately 30,000-40,000 are civilians actually killed by rebels / al Qaeda jihadists.

The grossly overestimated number of 1000 killed in the recent apparent chemical attack close to Damascus represents a small fraction of the most gruesome killings perpetuated by rebels in Syria.

Government’s forces in Syria have resisted an enormous aggression only because the majority of Syrians – across different ethnicities and religions – are uniting to oppose foreign al Qaeda terrorists’ invasion supported by the Saudi Arabia and apparently by us very soon.

I believe that the major misconception of our policy has been notion that once we overthrow legitimate Syrian government we will be able to support moderate Syrian groups that will prevail over Islamic extremists affiliated with the al Qaeda. This has never happened in the history and will not happen in Syria unless our military is on the ground fighting this war – which appropriately is not an option.

I hope Congress hears the majority American people asking NO INTERVENTION in Syria.
And if the US government gassed civilians to stay in power, we would deserve tomahawk missiles raining down on our defense infrastructure.

Secy Kerry said invading Syria with Tomahawk missiles is not war
If Syria attacked the US with tomahawk missiles it sure would be war!
Most Americans do. It is their representatives that willfully ignore it, and their constituents.

As a former Air Force officer and a member of the progressive left, I believe there are numerous good reasons not to act militarily in this conflict:

1. A limited strike will have little or no effect on altering Syrian government behavior, while a massive operation will only ensure that we are engaged in yet another unnecessary Middle East war.

2. We have no end game and there has been no real discussion about what happens next. If the first strike is ineffective, do we escalate? How much and for how long?

3. We have no strong backing from the international community. Even our closest ally, Britain, has backed away from military action. The UN is unlikely to offer any sanctions to support us.

4. We have no way of telling who such attacks will really benefit. Are we simply paving the way for radical, anti-American insurgents including Al Quaeda?

5. Launching yet another military adventure abroad simply distracts attention and diverts resources from the very real problems we have here at home.

We simply cannot afford to be the policeman of the world any more. Continuing to do so has hollowed out our economy, generated countless enemies, and discouraged our people. Only the permanent national security apparatus, which continues on no matter who is president, has a vested interest in more military action.
None of this will happen.
Definitely ignore all experts!  What do they know, right?
What would you do if you had family in Syria?

The congress should follow the UK parliament and, for once, pay attention to the people rather than the beltway "experts", lobbyists and pundits. The British parliamentarians did what they were elected to do, represent their people.

Prime Minister Cameron "gets it ", having accepted the result with good grace and in doing so enhanced his reputation. I don't know if this is what President Obama had in mind when he (rightly in my opinion) involved Congress, but a "no" vote would enable him to back down with similar grace. It would save him, and the nation, from overseas adventure that, as is always the case when western powers interfere in the middle east, would cause more problems than it solves.

Why would a smart tyrant like Assad bother with chemical weapons when he has killed by the tens of thousands with "regular" weapons and no one lifted a finger? What strategic advantage has this given him over the rebels?

Something is not kosher here.
NY TImes readers are just that — NY TImes readers. They are not a cross section of America.
Ah, but are the NYT readers the American people?

Maybe an extrapolation of Leona Hemsley's famous quote yields an answer.

"We don't pay taxes. Only the little people pay taxes."

The elites, and elected officials if not elites before taking office become elites while in office, run the show and operate by their own rules. Rarely, though it does happen, do populist notions take effect. For the proposed Syrian action not to occur, it's likely a coalition from the moneyed and power set would have to support that.

I have analyzed 100 top Readers' Picks, and found all but two writers against the US military intervention. Scaling up 98 times likes produces even much higher percentage of the opponents to this idea.

The statistics tell that almost no NYT reader supports it. Do our reps and elected leaders read what American people want? And if they do, why they do not care?
Yes , let's just trust the government, they must know what's best for us!
There is NO such thing as 'humanitarian' bombing.
England voted NO!

These posts... nothing but mass hysteria. People need to get their facts straight and stop reading between the lines. This isn't Iraq or Afghanistan. This is about a country the size of North Dakota that now has 2 million refugees and thousands of innocent civilians have died and will continue to die if the international community doesn't join forces. Just stop for a second to see the suffering of those people. It is so easy for you all to sit back, watch the news, enjoy the freedom you all take for granted and say, hey, this isn't my problem. Shame on you. This country has a moral obligation to go and help those people. I am proud of President Obama.

I just want to ride on my motorsickle.
And I don't want to die,
I just want to ride on my motorcy-

Obama can't "hold back" the military war establishment?  Of course he can!  He's the president for God's sake.  Obama is leading the war cry.

I am so profoundly disappointed in President Obama for this final (and giant) lapse of judgment (make no mistake after this he will have absolutely no political capital left). Up until now my biggest disappointment was that he didn't take on the "robber barron" banks who own this country and now I see he can't hold back the military war establishment and the strong Washington lobby (especially the Israeli lobby) in this march to an illegal and unnecessary war with Syria,. My heart goes out to the Syrian refugees and I will personally support any and every charity that is working to make their lives better.
Do you have a budget?  How much do you tip?

They don't want poeple to stay long and take up a table. They want them to get out quick so that they can get another party in. The initial meal yields more money than people lingering at a table ordering a little of this and that.
Think that idea through. Servers on commission would become salesmen, pushing the most profitable items, pressuring customers to order more food and drinks than they want. No. Bad idea!

It should have disappeared with the dinosaurs. Any other business knows that if they want good employees who will provide good customer service, you get them by paying good wages. You then supervise your employees - that is the job description of the cleverly named 'supervisor' after all. The supervisor recognizes outstanding employees with praise and raises, and identifies below-standard employees for training, coaching, and if necessary firing. In no other business is it the customer's job to sort out the good and bad employees and provide the good ones with a raise.

Ideally servers should be on a commission knowing that customers are going to stay longer and buy more if they are being well taken care of and having a good time. Top servers would still have the opportunity to make real money at high-end restaurants. Again, it would be up to the supervisor, not the customers, to maintain high standards of service by actually supervising his/her employees.

Deblasio's nose is getting bigger and bigger every time he speaks about the tale of two Deblasio's.  This man couldn't manage the public advocates office and has had a very high turnover of employees, has done nothing as a public advocate and if any one had a constituent problem in the past or currently good luck getting help from his office or getting them to answer the phone or answer an email. He's got a young staff where everyone has fancy titles but they do nothing.

"I made $3 billion, what did they do?"  Wow, he took more than he needed and then he took and took and took. This is a good thing? Let him say who paid the price and what good he did other than line his pockets.

Obama's genius move is that he has changed the subject of debate & focus in Congress to Syria instead of a debate centered around shutting down the government over funding the ACA.   If Congress approves action in Syria they can't very well turn around and shut down the government.

The President is a "Genius" for following the Constitution and American law? Next will we hear that John Kerry is also a "Genius" for his "explanations", during this week's Senate hearings, of the Administration's several positions, on its requirements for a resolution authorizing action in Syria?

This would be the same John Kerry that last week explained why his boss, the President, believed it unnecessary to even ask the Congress for such a resolution in the first place?

This is a cynical political decision based on political realities. The President is unpopular. The President's shifting opinions on the reasons for and his authority to, take unilateral (go it alone) action in Syria, are even more unpopular, especially among his own supporters.

There are only "Amateurs" here not "Geniuses"!

Maureen,

Politics indeed make for strange bedfellows. Boehner and Pelosi are working together! These days, also make for some delicious whining from all corners of the GOP. For example, Senator Jeff Flake taking the president to task for, gasp, making the GOP vote on something!

Flake to Kerry: "How can we assure or tell our constituents that this isn't political when you come, when the administration comes to the Congress to ask for authorization to take action that the president clearly has said he has authority to take?"

and the retort:

""Well Senator Flake," Kerry responded. "It's somewhat surprising to me that a member of Congress, particularly one on the Foreign Relations Committee, is going to question the president fulfilling the vision of the Founding Fathers when they wrote the Constitution and divided power on foreign policy.""

President Obama is a genius for having plopped a portion of this on Congress' lap.

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/03/jeff-flake-obama-syria_n_386248...

For what it's worth, I am a strong supporter of Israel who fears reprisals against Israel as a proxy for the U.S., should the U.S. strike Syria. To my mind, U.S. involvement in Syria would be to Israel's detriment.

There has to be a better way to send strong messages to the region. For that matter, I thought that the joint U.S.-Israeli military exercise in the Mediterranean sent a strong message to all concerned.
